There may be some doubt left whether Aeschylus actually knew the abstract word дгцлокдагсау or perhaps only a phrase such as ôfjfioç xqareîy which,  however,  would indicate a form of State in which the Demos was exercising supreme power.  Thus I believe that the two come essentially to the same thing.  The idea of democracy as well as an expression for this idea,  as confirmed by the passages mentioned,  were known to the poet,  either in the shape of the final abstract noun or as a verbal phrase of virtually the same meaning.  I really think the former possibility is far more likely.  Prof.  Debrunner ( see note 3 ),  without taking the evidence from the Suppliants into consideration,  has shown that the very words èrîfxoç xqareîy and they alone,  provide the exact meaning expressed in the abstract noun when fiist used.  According to him,  örjjuoxQarla was the only possible word to indicate government by the people,  a word shaped after the abstract nouns,  already in existence at that time,  indicating the rival forms of ment : fiovaqxia and oXiyaQxia.  Of these,  the former is used by Aeschylus { Sept,  881 ),  but it was known as early as Alcaeus ( 119 - 22,  27 ) ; it is clearly the earliest of the three,  and the first to introduce a composite word in which the first part referred to the subject,  and not to the object,  of ment's,  Xo express the conception of the people's rule,  & r ] fiaQxia was impossible,  as it was already used for the rule over,  not by,  the people'^ ; apart from that,  even if it referred to the subject of government,  it would,  just like monarchy and oligarchy,  express the rule over somebody else,  and that could hardly be the idea of the word needed^^.  Thus,  ôrjfioxQarla was coined ; it had no Grundwort^ no ôrjjbcoxQaxTjçy but it was most fertile
ovôéjtEQ cf. ,  e.  g. ,  J.  D.  Denniston,  Tbe Greek Par / icleSy 487.  It is Pelasgus who rules,  though not without the consent of the demos.  This is the democratic monarchy of the myth,  once more set against the absolute monarchy which is in the chorus' thoughts.  If it is not simply democracy,  it certainly does not contradict it. 
23.  I am not quite convinced that Debrunner is right in dating ôrjfioxQaria later than ohyaQXiOLy or at least whether we can be sure about it.  If I have rightly understood his view,  it would otherwise have been ôrjfioKQaTeia and not ôrjfwxgaria.  But can the ending not equally be influenced by fiovaQ^ia?  The form ohyaQX^a,  it is true,  is directly shaped after jxovaQxici,  and the rule of the ßaaiXelq in Hesiod's time or that of the noble clans in the seventh and sixth centuries may have been described by that name ; there was no other yet,  as far as we can tell.  But was there a name at all at that time?  At any rate,  wc shall see in the following section that the original opposites were archy« and »non - monarchy « ; these opposites,  w^hatever the name of the second,  seem earlier than the triad. 
24.  The ôij / ûLaQxoç was a magistrate in early Chios ( Tod,  no.  i,  3.  5.  26 ).  Here as well as in the later Athenian дгцладхоь,  the men administering the local demes of Attica,  ôfjfxoç is the object of rule. 
25.  We arc used to the idea that democracy means that the people are ruled by the people.  But when the word ôrjfioxgarla was first coined,  it cannot have included this almost metaphysical meaning.
